sub_topic: Identifying the cut vertices and bridges in a graph.
message_1:
Consider the following graph:

```
A -- B -- C -- D -- E
|         |
F -- G -- H
```

What are the cut vertices and bridges in this graph?
message_2:
A cut vertex (also known as an articulation point) is a vertex that, when removed along with its incident edges, increases the number of connected components in the graph. A bridge (also known as a cut edge) is an edge that, when removed, increases the number of connected components in the graph.

In the given graph, the cut vertices are B, C, and H. Removing any of these vertices and their incident edges will increase the number of connected components.

The bridges in the graph are the edges (B, C), (C, D), and (C, H). Removing any of these edges will increase the number of connected components.
